channel.title: Bloomberg Markets

item.title: BYD’s Hong Kong Shares Hit Record Premium Over Onshore Stock
item.description: BYD Co.’s shares rose to a record high in Hong Kong, expanding their premium over those trading on the mainland to the highest level ever.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Yang

item.title: South Africa Arbiter Proposes More Pay to Avoid Logistics Strike
item.description: A third-party arbiter proposed a higher wage offer to South Africa’s state-owned ports and rail company and its unions in a bid to stave off a potential strike by thousands of logistics workers.
item.dc:creator: Ana Monteiro

media:content.media:description: A worker walks through the terminal as a rail mounted gantry crane, manufactured by Terex Corp., lifts a shipping container on the dockside at the Port of Durban, operated by Transnet SOC Holdings Ltd.'s Ports Authority, in Durban, South Africa, on Friday, May 25, 2018. Transnet last year reduced its seven-year capital-investment plan by 17 percent to 229.2 billion rand in response to lower-than-anticipated freight demand. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: Chinese Authorities Question Metals Bosses in Smuggling Probe
item.description: Chinese authorities have questioned the heads of some of the country’s leading metals merchants and producers as part of an intensifying effort to crack down on critical-minerals smuggling, according to people familiar with the situation.
item.dc:creator: Julian Luk, Alfred Cang

item.title: Oil Climbs on Report That Israel Is Preparing to Strike Iran
item.description: Oil jumped following a CNN report that new US intelligence suggests Israel is preparing for a potential strike on Iranian nuclear facilities.
item.dc:creator: Rob Verdonck, Yongchang Chin

media:content.media:description: The Bushehr nuclear power plant in Bushehr province, Iran. Source: NurPhoto/NurPhoto

item.title: EU Sanctions Ships That Moved LNG From Russia’s Yamal Plant
item.description: The European Union imposed sanctions on three vessels that helped move gas cargoes from Russia’s Yamal LNG project, further squeezing Moscow’s energy revenues.
item.dc:creator: Anna Shiryaevskaya

media:content.media:description: A gas flare, also known as a flare stack, burns at the Yamal LNG plant, operated by Novatek PJSC, in Sabetta, Russia, on Wednesday, Aug. 8, 2018. Novatek is one of the largest independent natural gas producers in Russia.

item.title: Morgan Stanley Strategists Say Buy America Except the Dollar
item.description: Morgan Stanley has raised its call on US stocks and Treasuries on expectations that a slew of future interest-rate cuts by the Federal Reserve will support bonds and boost company earnings.
item.dc:creator: Winnie Hsu, Abhishek Vishnoi

item.title: Fed's Daly, Hammack on Outlook for US Economy
item.description: San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly and Cleveland Fed President Beth Hammack talk about their outlook for the US economy and adopting a wait-and-see approach to policy, in an event moderated by Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic. They all spoke at the Atlanta Fed's "Financial Intermediation in Transition" conference. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Rises on Israel-Iran Report, Dollar Weakens: Markets Wrap
item.description: Oil rose on a CNN report that new US intelligence suggested Israel is preparing for a potential strike on Iranian nuclear facilities.
item.dc:creator: Anand Krishnamoorthy

item.title: World’s Biggest Listing Gets Bigger After CATL Exercises Option
item.description: Contemporary Amperex Technology Co. Ltd. has raised HK$41 billion ($5.2 billion) for its Hong Kong share sale after arrangers of the deal exercised the so-called greenshoe option to increase the offering, making the world’s biggest listing this year even bigger.
item.dc:creator: Dave Sebastian

media:content.media:description: CATL founder Robin Zeng at the company's listing ceremony on May 20. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

item.title: HSBC's Joe Little on the End of American Exceptionalism
item.description: Joe Little, Global Chief Strategist at HSBC Global Asset Management, unpacks the concept of the "end of exceptionalism" — a term he notes is often poorly defined. Little shares his insights on where some cracks are starting to show in US equities and the dollar, and explains why these developments are prompting some investors to diversify more of their assets into overseas alternatives. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US Sets the Stage for Duties on Battery Materials From China
item.description: The US Commerce Department set the stage for anti-subsidy duties on imports of key battery components from China, after concluding materials had been unfairly subsidized.
item.dc:creator: Tope Alake

item.title: G-7 Finance Ministers Aim to Avoid Public Spats With US Despite Trade Turmoil
item.description: Finance ministers who’ve gathered in Canada for a Group of Seven meeting this week face a difficult task — trying to find common ground on trade issues while avoiding public conflict with US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Erik Hertzberg, Laura Dhillon Kane

media:content.media:description: Tourists take photos with the Banff town sign, ahead of the G7 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors' Meeting in Banff, Alberta, Canada on May 20, 2025. Top finance leaders from the G7 nations gather in Canada starting Tuesday, with concerns including war in Ukraine at the fore while the advanced economies grapple with fallout from US President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs. (Photo by Cole Burston / AFP) (Photo by COLE BURSTON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Indian Equity Capital Market Action Resumes Amid Tariff Uncertainty
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Ashutosh Joshi

item.title: Goldman Says Hedge Funds Cut Magnificent Seven, Bought China Stocks
item.description: Hedge funds cut their holdings of the so-called Magnificent Seven technology stocks while increasing exposure to Chinese companies listed in the US during the first quarter, according to Goldman Sachs Group Inc. strategists.
item.dc:creator: Abhishek Vishnoi

item.title: Buyers Recoil From Japanese Bonds in Warning on BOJ Balance-Sheet Cuts
item.description: Japan’s sovereign debt market is flashing a warning to the central bank that dialing back its bond purchases needs to be done with great care.
item.dc:creator: Mia Glass, Alice French

item.title: China-US Trade Soars as Exporters Race to Hit Trade Truce Window
item.description: A temporary trade truce between the world’s two largest economies has sparked a knee-jerk bounce across China’s ports and factory floors.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Katia Dmitrieva, Weilun Soon

item.title: 2025 Qatar Economic Forum Day One Highlights
item.description: Highlights from day one of the 2025 Qatar Economic Forum, Powered by Bloomberg. World leaders and international CEOs share unique perspectives on how the global economy is transforming in Doha, Qatar. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Goldman Sachs On How Israel-Iran Tensions May Impact Oil Price
item.description: A possible strike on Iranian nuclear facilities could disrupt the supply of oil, according to Goldman Sachs Co-Head of Global Commodities Research Samantha Dart. While this would normally drive prices upwards, Dart adds the impact may be moderated over time by excess capacity in other OPEC countries. Dart speaks on Bloomberg's The Asia Trade. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: New World Asks Banks to Refinance $11 Billion Loans by June
item.description: New World Development Co. has asked banks to refinance HK$87.5 billion ($11.2 billion) of its loans by the end of June, according to people familiar with the matter, as the cash-strapped builder seeks to quickly shore up its liquidity.
item.dc:creator: Apple Ka Ying Li, Trista Xinyi Luo, Pearl Liu

media:content.media:description: The State Pavilia residential project under construction, developed by New World Development Co., in Hong Kong. Photographer: Chan Long Hei/Bloomberg

item.title: Traders Brace for Treasury 10-Year Yield at 5% as Mood Sours
item.description: Traders are piling into bets that long-term Treasury yields will surge on concerns over the US government’s swelling debt and deficits, a situation made more precarious by President Donald Trump’s tax-cut bill.
item.dc:creator: Edward Bolingbroke

item.title: China Ran Record Budget Deficit With Spending Blitz Amid Tariffs
item.description: China’s fiscal stimulus pushed its four-month budget deficit to a record high, as the government ramped up support for the economy during an escalation in its trade conflict with the US.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Fran Wang

item.title: London Metal Exchange CEO on Setting Up Hong Kong Warehouses
item.description:
London Metal Exchange CEO Matthew Chamberlain discusses the company's plans to set up warehouses in Hong Kong. According to Chamberlain, the city is a "higher cost jurisdiction" but clients want facilities "close to the metal centers of mainland China" and will pay for "that logistical convenience." He speaks on Bloomberg Television.
(Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Goldman Warns Europe’s Gas Refill at Risk if Prices Drop Further
item.description: Europe can secure enough liquefied natural gas to refill storage for next winter at current prices, but the region faces competition for supply should prices fall further, according to Goldman Sachs Group Inc.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Stapczynski, Paul Allen

item.title: Asus Co-CEO on Tariffs Impact, AI
item.description: Asus Co-CEO Samson Hu says the company anticipates raising prices by 5-10% due to US tariff policy and the costs of supply chain diversification. Speaking with Bloomberg News' Annabelle Droulers on the sidelines of Computex Taipei 2025, Hu also stated that he foresees it will be another one to two years before AI driven upgrade cycle will take hold. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: New Fortress Energy Disqualified From Puerto Rico Power Auction
item.description: New Fortress Energy has been disqualified from an auction held by the Puerto Rican government to secure temporary power generation, the latest setback for billionaire Wes Edens’ troubled company.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Liao, Jim Wyss

media:content.media:description: Wes Edens Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: S&P 500 Falls After $8.6 Trillion Surge From Lows | Bloomberg: The Close 05/20/2025
item.description: Bloomberg Television brings you the latest news and analysis leading up to the final minutes and seconds before and after the closing bell on Wall Street. Today's guests are Jitania Kandhari, Morgan Stanley, Wendy Schiller, Brown University, Michael Baker, DA Davidson, Rich Clarida, PIMCO, Jody Lurie, Bloomberg Intelligence, David Bailin, CIO Group, Donald Trump, Rashaan Reid, BofA, Elon Musk from QEF, Ed Ludlow, Bloomberg News, Jackie Davalos, Bloomberg News, Kevin Kajiwara, Teneo, Adrienne Yih, Barclays. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Toyota Industries Investor Zennor Wants Minority Safeguards
item.description: Toyota Industries Corp. investor Zennor Asset Management LLP said a plan by Toyota Motor Corp. Chairman Akio Toyoda to take over the Japanese auto parts maker raises governance issues and may undermine minority shareholders’ interests.
item.dc:creator: Momoka Yokoyama, Hideyuki Sano

item.title: Trump Sets Stage to Sell Ocean Mining Rights Off American Samoa
item.description: The Trump administration is setting the stage to sell mining rights off the coast of American Samoa as demand surges for critical materials used in electric vehicle batteries, smart phones and other technology.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: APIA, SAMOA - SEPTEMBER 30: A view of new fales on September 30, 2010 in Maninoa, Samoa. 189 people were killed and hundreds more injured in Samoa, American Samoa, and Tonga in 2009. (Photo by Hannah Peters/Getty Images) Photographer: Hannah Peters/Getty Images AsiaPac

item.title: Wolfspeed Put Options Surge Before Report on Bankruptcy Plans
item.description: Traders ramped up bearish bets Tuesday on Wolfspeed Inc., before the Wall Street Journal reported after regular market hours that the ailing chip component maker is preparing to file for bankruptcy protection within weeks.
item.dc:creator: David Marino, Bernard Goyder

media:content.media:description: The Wolfspeed, Inc. logo on a smartphone screen in Reno, United States, on January 3, 2025.

item.title: S&P 500 Falls After $8.6 Trillion Surge From Lows: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street’s rally took a breather on Tuesday, with stocks falling as traders awaited fresh catalysts after a six-day run that put the S&P 500 up almost 20% from its April lows.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth
